awd_titl_txt: Assemblies of Metal Nanoparticles and Single Quantum Dots with Low-Power, Ultrafast Nonlinear Optical Response
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to continue to build faster, more powerful computers is reaching a limit set by the amount of energy needed to run the computers. It may be possible to overcome this energy barrier by replacing electronic components, which use electrical current to process information, with photonic components, which use light to process information, but only if ultrafast, ultrasmall, and ultra-low-power photonic devices can be built. This project develops one class of these devices, which can serve to control the flow of light in future all-optical computers. This is accomplished by using chemical means to produce nanometer-scale metal and semiconductor particles and to induce strong optical interactions among the particles by assembling them into controlled hybrid arrangements.  These scientific goals are integrated with efforts to broaden the diversity of the scientific workforce, through the involvement of high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students in cutting-edge research, particularly students from underrepresented groups, female students, and veterans.

The objective of this project is to produce assemblies of metal nanoparticles (MNPs) and single quantum dots (QDs) with nonlinear optical response at ultralow incident powers. The nonlinearity arises due to near-field optical interactions among the nanoparticles and is qualitatively different from the response of the components separately. Assemblies of colloidal QDs and MNPs with strong interparticle interactions are fabricated through the chemical synthesis of QDs and anisotropic gold nanoparticles (nanorods or bipyramids), the selective covalent binding of single QDs to the ends of the MNPs to form MNP-QD-MNP trimers, and the separation of these trimers from smaller and larger assemblies. Optical functionality is verified by correlated linear and nonlinear optical spectroscopy and electron-microscope imaging of individual assemblies. Experimental results are compared to numerical simulations, enabling detailed understanding of structure-property relationships and optimization of the nonlinear response.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When the dimensions of materials are reduced to the nanometer scale, they can interact with light very differently than bulk materials do. The key examples are semiconductor nanocrystals, or quantum dots, which emit light at wavelengths that depend on their diameters, and metal nanoparticles, which strongly absorb and scatter light at wavelengths that depend on their size and shape, and which can confine optical energy to dimensions much smaller than the wavelength of light. Bringing these two nanomaterials together leads to an even broader range of optical properties, such as increasing the brightness of the quantum dots and selectively canceling out the absorption and scattering of the metal nanoparticles, phenomena that have the potential to enable new classical and quantum information-processing technologies. However, previous demonstrations of the assembly of metal and semiconductor nanoparticles for novel optical properties relied on complex fabrication techniques, used sophisticated scanning-probe setups, or produced a very small fraction of the target assemblies. In this project, we developed benchtop chemical methods to produce macroscopic numbers of the target assemblies. Bipyramidal gold nanoparticles and semiconductor quantum dots were produced using colloidal synthesis techniques. Functional molecules were selectively attached to the tips of the bipyramids, and complementary molecules were attached to the quantum dots. A controlled reaction between these pairs of molecules led to the attachment of the quantum dots to the ends of the bipyramids. The target assembly -- a single quantum dot between a pair of end-to-end bipyramids -- was achieved with a yield of approximately 25%. This assembly was chosen because it was predicted to lead to strong interactions between the metal and semiconductor components, and this was verified through measurements of the scattering and emission of light from single assemblies. The techniques developed for selective functionalization and binding of the nanoparticles are expected to find applications in the development of functional colloidal nanomaterials beyond the metal-semiconductor assemblies that are the focus of this project. Future directions include the purification of the target assemblies from byproducts (of assemblies with too many or too few nanoparticles) and the incorporation of the assemblies into photonic structures for next-generation optical devices.
